results.title: The Australian eye I
results.creator_credit: David Muir, Malcolm Otton and Film Australia
results.brief_description: Each film examines in detail one master work in the Art Gallery of N.S.W’s collection, drawing upon related material such as preliminary sketches and studies, and also upon writings or other records which throw light on its creation.

results.title: The Australian Bicentennial Golf Classic
results.brief_description: The prestigious and classic Australian golfing event, held at the Royal Melbourne Golf course, is one of Australia’s most important Bicentennial sports event. A sensational field of competitors compete for the highest prize money ever offered in an Australian golfing event. The world’s number one golfer, and one of Australia’s greatest sportsmen, Greg Norman, pairs head to head against “Golfer of the Century” Jack Nicklaus. Includes Roger Davis, Nick Faldo and many more of golf’s champion players.

results.title: The Audition
results.creator_credit: C B Wismar and Counterpoint Films
results.brief_description: A young man comes into a seemingly empty theatre for an audition. He is not given a script but it is clear to the invisible director that he can portray surprise & anger can he portray love? Understanding? Pity? Concern? An allegorical tale of life, the young man it appears is the director as well.

results.title: The Atomic theory
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “Atomic physics: an historical approach”.
This film, in five parts, is designed for use in the Science Departments of universities, technical colleges, and schools teaching advanced physics. Each part of the film is usable independently from the other four parts. Part 1 deals with the early days in which the properties of the elements were systematized in terms of atomic theory. Suitable for students 15+.

group_siblings.title: Neutron smashing: the discovery of the atom
The Nuclear structure of the atom

results.title: The Atom: a closer look
results.creator_credit: Corporate Productions and Walt Disney Educational Media Company
results.brief_description: Uses animation and live-action to illustrate the history of atomic theory, the structure of the atom and its nucleus, how nuclear energy is generated, radiation and the problems of nuclear waste disposal. Although basically factual, the program stresses the fact that the atom is neither good nor evil, and that it is man’s responsibility to decide whether atomic power will either create or destroy. Made pre Chernobyl but an excellent introduction to atomic theory. Suitable for middle and upper secondary levels.

results.title: The Atom and industry
results.creator_credit: Warren P. Everote and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description: Demonstrates how radio-isotopes are providing new techniques of measurement and quality control in a wide variety of industries. Illustrates the following; radio-active “tagging” or identification of batches of crude oil in the petroleum industry; measurement of wear in petrol engines by using radio-active piston rings; measurement and control of thickness of materials produced in sheet form; testing for flaws in casting.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Warren P. Everote and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films

results.title: The Atom and archaeology
results.creator_credit: Peter Mertens and Handel Film Corporation
results.brief_description: Shows how nuclear and radiation techniques, such as carbon-14 dating, thermoluminescence, atomic fingerprinting, and radiography, have helped archeologists discover new facts about the past. Hitherto impenetrable barriers of time are broken, and new data about ancient civilisations revealed. Pioneer work in progress at leading research centres in the USA is shown.

results.title: The Atlantic community: introducing Turkey
results.creator_credit: Vittorio Gallo, Europa Telefilm and North Atlantic Treaty Organization
results.brief_description: The third largest country in NATO, Turkey holds a geographical position of great strategic importance. In less than 40 years since the social and economic revolution begun by Kemal Ataturk, Turkey has made rapid progress in industry and in the raising of her living standards.
